review.title: Echoes of Persuasion: The Effect of Euphony in Persuasive Communication
review.abstract: While the effect of various lexical, syntactic, semantic and stylistic features have been addressed in persuasive language from a computational point of view, the persuasive effect of phonetics has received little attention. By modeling a notion of euphony and analyzing four datasets comprising persuasive and non-persuasive sentences in different domains (political speeches, movie quotes, slogans and tweets), we explore the impact of sounds on different forms of persuasiveness. We conduct a series of analyses and prediction experiments within and across datasets. Our results highlight the positive role of phonetic devices on persuasion.

We conduct a series of analyses and predictive experiments within and across sets of data. Our results underline the positive role of phonetic devices in persuasive work.

sections.heading: 2 Related Work
sections.text: In the following, we first review some NLP studies that deal with linguistic characteristics of successful communication, and then summarize a selection of studies that focus on the effects of phonetics on persuasive power.

sections.heading: 2.1 NLP studies on persuasion
sections.text: Berger and Milkman (2009) focus on a particular form of persuasive power by using New York Times articles to examine the relationship between virility (i.e. the tendency of content circulating on the Web) and emotions aroused by the content, and perform semi-automatic sentiment analyses to quantify the affectivity and emotionality of each article. Results suggest a strong relationship between affect and virility, in this case measured by the number of people who sent each article by e-mail. As suggested by the authors, this metric represents a form of "narrative casting," as opposed to other "broadcasting" actions such as sharing on Twitter. Another line of research examines the impact of different textual characteristics on audience reactions. Guerini et al (2011) correlates several viral phenomena with the formulation of a post, while Guerini et al al al al al al al al al al downloadable (2012) presents the impact of a particular person's readability to the abstract nature of a booklet, such as the number of abstract features.

We compare three different sets of characteristics, namely phonetics, n-gram and their combination, to understand whether phonetic information can improve the performance of standard lexical approaches. Similar to Danescu-Niculescu-Mizil et al. (2012) and Tan et al. (2014), we formulate a pair-wise classification problem so that in a pair (s1, s2) consisting of sentences s1 and s2, our goal is to determine the more convincing label (i.e., the one on the left or right).

sections.heading: 6.1 Dataset and preprocessing
sections.text: For the prediction experiments, we used the four sets of data described in Section 4 (i.e. CORPS, Twitter, Slogan, and Movie), which all consist of a convincing sentence P and its unconvincing counterpart (¬ P), marked either as left or right. To make the positions of the sentences in a pair irrelevant (i.e. to establish symmetry), we added for each instance that occurs in the original records (e.g. (s1, s2) labeled left), another instance that contains the same sentence pair in reverse order (i.e. (s2, s1) labeled right). As a pre-processing step, all sentences were symbolized by Stanford CoreNLP (Manning et al., 2014).

sections.heading: 6.2 Classifier and features
sections.text: We performed a 10-fold cross-validation on each set of data and experimented with three sets of characteristics using a classifier from the Support Vector Machine (SVM) (Cortes and Vapnik, 1995). Due to its characteristic characteristic, we preferred SVM as a classifier to perform well, especially for high-dimensional data (Weichselbraun et al., 2011). The first set of characteristics consists of the phonetic characteristics (i.e. plosive, alphabetization, rhymes and homogeneity values as described in Section 3); the second set of characteristics consists of a standard bag of verbs, including unigrams, bigrams and trigrams; all non-ascertaining characters, punctuations and numbers were ignored; URLs and mentions in Twitter data were replaced by tags (i.e. URLs and MENTION or MENTION); and the ungrained characteristics were filtered out.

sections.heading: 6.3 Within-dataset experiments
sections.text: In Table 5, for each data set listed in the first column, we report in the following columns on the performance of the respective best model, which has 10-fold cross-validation using i) phonetic characteristics only (phonetic), ii) n-gram only (N-gram), iii) both phonetic and ngrammatic characteristics (all). As already mentioned, for each pair (s1, s2) consisting of sentences s1 and s2, our data set becomes another pair with the same sentences in reverse order (i.e., s2, s1), resulting in a symmetrical and balanced dataset. Therefore, the classification performance is measured in terms of accuracy (i.e. the percentage of pairs whose labels were correctly predicted). For each accuracy, we also report the number of selected characteristics and the core degree of the corresponding model.

sections.heading: 6.4 Cross-dataset experiments
sections.text: After observing that the combination of phonetic and n-gram features can be effective in the withindataset prediction experiments, we went a step further and examined the interaction of the three character sets between the data sets. More specifically, we classified each data set with the best models (one for each character set) trained on the other data sets. In this regard, the results of the cross-dataset experiments can also be interpreted as a measure of the degree of compatibility between these types of persuasion. In Table 7, we present the results of the crossdataset prediction experiments. For each training and test set, we report on the accuracy of the best models, one for each feature, based on cross-validation on the training set.

sections.heading: 7 Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we focused on the effects of a number of phonetic features - namely rhymes, alliteration, homogeneity, and plosive - on various forms of persuasive power, including the memorability of slogans and film quotes, retweet counting of tweets, and the effectiveness of political speech. We conducted our analysis and experiments on four sets of data containing pairs of a persuasive sentence and an unconvincing counterpart. Our data analysis shows that convincing sentences are generally euphoric, and the key role that phonetic features play is confirmed by predictive experiments in which we observed that phonetic features consistently help to detect persuasive power. Combined with lexical features, they help to improve the classification performance of three of the four sets of data we considered. The key role that phonetic features play is further enhanced by the transboundary data experiments alone that we observed overlapping features in the phonetic ones.
